You know how to solve this little conundrum, right? Just grasp the spaghetti so that your fingers are almost touching and then proceed to break it. The most of the energy from the fracture will be absorbed/dampened by your fingers and won't cause those cascading fractures. You might still get some miniscule amount of fracturing between your fingers, but at least you've stopped the propagation. You could also borrow a technique that's used for glass fiber optic cutting and use a very hard, very sharp instrument to introduce a score line around the pasta, weakening it in that local area, and then it will easily cleave at that boundary. I wouldn't be surprised if that's exactly how they do it at the factory to reduce product loss.

simplerly put, the most efficient form of the energy required to bend the spaghetti isn't equal to the tensile/compressive properties of the material's potential .

put simply, applying energy forms a wave in this material.  its rigidity can't match the shape of this wave, as the peek increase exponentially equal to the distance of the ends become closer, if you draw this imaginary wave then you'll see two crossing point.  the material can't continue to give so it's storing resistance force, these are the outer breakage points.  the wave divides the pieces into three equal parts to best of the potential capacitance for energy, but we already know the material is changing density at curve's most resistant areas.  the inner most breakage point happens from the tensile and compression strength rapidly changing, and the material's inability to meet the demands.

its two things happening at once mirroring one another.  when you push on the spaghetti from both sides you are sending and energy wave through the spaghetti, but moving one side alone will send energy from the other side as well, compressing both sides multiplies your input, these mirror one another and meet right at where it breaks at the peak moment of these waves of energy adding together, at points where the "tensile" strength fails. .  but thats not all that happens because spaghetti has tensile strength and compressive strength, the longer the noodle vs shorter, the radius at the point of max tensile meeting compressive, as the outside parts start to spring back straight, the rigidity of the outer parts vs the center, the mass of the outer ends vs where it is held is greater due to length, so it cones these forces due to changes in how one end can reform vs the other.  the center is then compressed differently on both sides of the noodles creating a denser inner or under part and less dense outside or upper due to direction of the bend or energy applied, so this change in hardness vs the spring effect of a harder material cause the center to break as well.  you have energy that isn't necessarily vibration, and you have the generic folding fatigue of matter.  so its 2 version of 2 things happening at once.  if you look at it like polar moment, this is pretty much what is happening to the center part, like a polar moment of inertia meeting now two different densities in one material and something is going to behave differently than the other.  to remain stable, matter needs no energy until enough is applied to alter it's initial state.  n we know this because when you bend spaghetti far enough without it breaking, it won't return to it's original straightness.  always bends a bit.  so its not a very solid material as one thinks, just rigid on the outside and softer on the inside.  the outside most part is spread thinner to the inside mass, and inside most curve is made harder and more rigid.  as they then return to form this happens at different speeds due to the different density causing it to snap.  not that hard to figure out In my opinion it is happening due to the elasticity of spaghetti. It is enough to bend it in such a way that it doesn’t create the most pressure in the middle point but on two points around the middle. That should be because the middle point is robust enough to contribute to the force applied on these two points. Think of it as bending a card, the middle point is used to create pressure on the two sides, which in this case you’ll notice on your fingers. When you let go the two sides will snap forward. That’s what I believe should the answer

when I first saw this to happen with spaghetti, I thought it had something to do with a almost whip like effect causing stress on the longer piece. Like this:
1. first break happens.
2. the both the ends try to straighten out.
3. the longer piece at the part closest to your hand strightens out faster then the rest of the spagghetti piece making it bow while the tip tries to speed up, to the point to where it snaps because the bend is over the thresshold of snapping.

Nice video but bad conclusion. At 2283.241ms you can already see the second crack while the spaghetto is still curved. There must be a wave traveling faster than the straightening one. To me, it is a compression wave, as they actually travel faster.
My theory is: The spaghetto doesn't break instantaneously along its section, but it first break at the upper side, where there is tension. As result of this collapse of the tension stress, a compression wave starts moving along the spaghetto until the combination with the pre-existing compression status in the lower side due to the bending causes a fragile rupture where the material is less resistant. This would cause a tension wave going back through the separated piece and overlapping the tension due to bending status and possibly causing a further rupture.

I have my own theory as to why it happens that way.

If you imagine the tension could be visualised using different colours for different levels of stress- say a gradient of green to red [unstressed to maximum stress]- you would be able to see a patch of red at what we can call the apex of the parabola or just the top of the curve. The spaghetti is going to break somewhere in that region, loaded with potential energy- provided there is no unusual weakness anywhere further down the line somewhere.
So there will be small areas in that critical area that are naturally the weakest parts of it- the very weakest of which will of course be the point at which the initial give-way takes place. This is physically connected to the other weakest areas- or points where fracture is naturally determined most likely to occur- by pasta with greater integrity; which will immediately transmit the sudden energy change caused by the fracture, the shock of which is sufficient to overwhelm at at least one other of those weaker sites already near breaking point. Ping!

Stopped at 2:11 to see if I could figure out why it snaps and here’s my guess after thinking about it for about 45 seconds.
A dry spaghetti noodle is very flexible and that feature gives the normally stable point of failure you would find in a rigid object like a stick the ability to split into two points point of failure because the fulcrum effect of using two finger on each side to break the noodle causes the middle of the noodle to want to flatten out thus making a low tension spot in the middle with two higher tension spots on both sides of the lower tension middle . I hypothesized that if you broke the spaghetti noodle using one finger on each side that you will have a better chance at breaking it into 2 pieces instead of 3+ pieces. I tested this and it worked on 4 out of 4 noodles. The dough molecules not all being oriented in the same direction also probably plays a part in it somehow.
Let’s see if I’m right.

This is a very intriguing phenomenon and i watched with interest your video, but i do not agree with your conclusions.
Here is mine.
What we are looking at here is curvature and therefore moment, but we are not able to see the actual tension status of the spaghetti, then we might have overlooked forces.
What moves faster is the compression/tension wave as axial stiffness is way higher the flexural one.
When the breakage occurs obviously the crack starts from the side in tension of the spaghetti, that suddenly make the tension falling to zero while the under compression side is still not broken. Then you can see this like a compression status that overlaps the bending with a wawe starting from the breakage point that travels along the spaghetti at the "sound speed" that in a solid is incredibly higher than in air, this compression as said overlaps the existing status causing the existing tension to fall down and the compression to increase and eventually a fragile rupture in a point where the spaghetti is weaker. But that wawe cross the broken section and is potentially able to cause other ruptures along the spaghetti. In fact, the second fracture occurs when you are still at about one third of the straightening process.

(wall of text, proceed at own risk;)



You told us that the spaghetti breaks into three because when one point of a side snaps and the rest of the other side is now free from tension and tries to straighten itself to a stable form, it snaps from that other side as well because as it tries to straighten the whole side, it is even more curved and it breaks as it cannot hold itself together. Now, if we take the spaghetti and break it at the distant sides, will it still break into three? I think not, because as the spaghetti now has less mass to deal with, it does not have enough mass to have such a problem (by problem I am referring to the "one side gets the message slower" problem). The way I see it, I would formulate the explanation a little differently (to suit my own logic better): So when the 1rst break happens, torque disappears and both sides start to straighten. because both parts of the spaghetti are still leaning on each other, the straightening creates an extra push and it's that extra push that creates extra torque further along, triggering the second break. From an architect's point of view, this problem can be described as a 2 pinned arch where your fingers act as the rotating pin connections. When you apply a uniform load to a two pinned arch and see how it deflects (via a bending moment diagram), there are two point that stay fixed. which are located between the middle part that deflect down and the sides that deflect out.

Understanding the problem in terms of building science/structural engineering might give a more complete answer to the problem because it provides the answers to addition questions: " Why does the spaghetti not break in the middle?" "Why is the break generally symmetric?" and even "why does it sometimes break into 3?"

I would love to see another video where you could ask a structural engineer about this in term of 2 pinned arches.

Okay so I thought about it. First you have to understand the characteristics of spaghetti. The outside has a much higher cohesion rate than the inside. There is a high rigidity overall as well. So as you bend both ends you compress the center. What happens next is that the center  fails before the outside does. So all that's left is a thin outer shell. If you can precisely alter the surface layer so that it is more flexible and the center breaks first it should break in only one place. At a microscopic level basically small cracks zip across the surface and since the surface was holding it together when it goes the rest of it goes. This is more a material physics problem as opposed to particle physics.  Too bad goyum don't get prizes for nobel physics The main aspect at play  is the ratio of  semi-homogeneous surface rigidity to internal rigidity.  These fractures are compression fractures. By altering the surface characteristics you can change how it breaks. put it in hot water and pull it out before it's fully cooked and it snaps in half

Very interesting, but I think it would have been better if you'd taken more time unpacking the technical jargon in the explanation section, for those that don't know what counter-torque and a flexural wave are. The description at this point suggests that the spaghetti is straightening out in a way that doesn't seem to imply a tighter bend at the second fracture position, the way I hear it. Actually, as I write this, I start to doubt the explanation. I'm no physicist or engineer, but I wonder if, after the tension is released by the first fracture, the now freed pieces of spaghetti are accelerated rapidly by the forces at the fingers and thumbs, beyond the tensile strength of the free ends (already under strain), particularly on the longer side. I guess one way to test this would be to find by experimentation the angle at which pieces of spaghetti break on average, then bend a piece to that degree, hopefully just shy of breaking, then releasing one end suddenly from a standstill (like you might casually flick it from a fingernail, but with more control). This would presumably put the piece under the sudden acceleration I'm suggesting. Do you think this might cause it to break? Anyway, thanks, I'm sure I'm slightly smarter for thinking about that, whatever the right answer is.

we don't have to focus our energy in break it in a single point. we just try to bend it and the spaghetti breaks itself. and spag strand is pretty brittle enough to do that. idk what will happen if you try to bend a metal rod doing the same motion as trying to break a spag stand. that would be a pretty cool experiment

but ya i think its because we focus all our energy on a single point which is why they break in half.
ans if we don't really try to focus it on one point it breaks in pieces. plus.. when spaghetti bends, they don't bend even. which is probably why they break into pieces instead of just two pieces. multiple breaking points are formed because of that.

no focus point: breaks into multiple pieces

Theory from the 40k fps. I think that when it snaps, it starts bending back so quick (slot of force) that it snaps again. Since spaghetti is a bit bendier than like a pencil, it reacts this way

Theory Time!:
You said how the piece of the spaghetti snapped at almost the same time? That's exactly it. They both snap very quickly, therefore the pressure from the push doesn't go away, it keeps on going. It doesn't have time to go, so instead the pressure from the push thinks it's going to snap it, on both sides. And it doesn't have the time to say, " Hey buddy, I'm snapping it ." Also how thin it is goes into this theory. The spaghetti can be easily snapped because it's so weak. And that's why it snaps fast.

Destin, thank you for making such great videos! I know almost nothing about physics, so sorry if this makes no sense, but I'm kind of obsessed with this now and I have some questions.

So spaghetti breaks into 3 or more pieces because of cascading fractures, but why does this happen to spaghetti, and not other rod-shaped objects? Why do other things, like pencils, break in a different way, into only 2 pieces? What's the difference? Is it because spaghetti is made of a more flexible material than a pencil? Is it because spaghetti is thinner and longer than a pencil?

I'm really bummed that I don't have any spaghetti right now, but I'm breaking soba noodles instead. They're roughly the same size and shape as spaghetti, but a pretty different texture. I'm breaking the whole noodles into pieces, then breaking those pieces into smaller pieces, and so on, until the pieces are too small to break. It seems almost 50/50 on whether they break into 2 pieces or 3, but here's something that's kind of freaking me out:

Now these are really rough because the noodles don't actually break perfectly in half BUT: A whole soba noodle breaks with cascading fractures often. A half noodle, even more often. A quarter noodle, less often. An eighth-of a noodle, never. Why does the half noodle have cascading fractures more often than the whole noodle? Is there some kind of sweet spot here? And what would happen if someone made an insanely long noodle that was still the same thickness as normal spaghetti, and broke that?

I want to get some actual spaghetti and other types of noodles and write down how often the cascading fractures are happening with each different length and type of noodle. I see so many potential patterns there but it's frustrating because, just snapping a few soba noodles, there seem to be a million variables at work. I think length of noodle, type of noodle (material), position of fingers on the noodle (closer or farther away from center), and the speed at which I break it all seem to make a difference.

I would describe what I am seeing this way.  When the first break occurs in pure bending (tensile failure on the outside of the curve) the free end springs back becausde of the stored compression and tensile forces, in a wave that starts at the break.  Near the break, this is just a reease of energy, but that release gets converted into kinetic energy that causes the free end to rebound away from the curve, until a reverse curve and reversed tensile and compression forces are stored. 

At about the point where the reverse bend is about6 the same as the original bend, the bending is replaced with almost pure shear (equal bends in two opposite directions must meet at an inflection point of no bending, but pure shear force).  And the failure there produces much higher seperation acceleration at right angles to the strand, like a shear fault breaking, than the original break did.

There is a method to breaking spaghetti in two (most of the time), whereby you start to bend it as normal, but stop half way to breaking point and twist your wrists inwards. This re-straightens the point near your hands and forces all the curve onto a shorter length of spaghetti, where it breaks.

This fits well with the theory demonstrated in this video, since the spaghetti doesn't have a uniform curve which is trying to straighten out.

At the risk of being way too technical.
...
I can see that when the first break occurs, there is a transverse wave sent down the shaft in both directions away from the break.  This is a wave that is up and down.  It is due to the release of stress of the first break allowing the two ends to become "un bent" (no stress).   Since it has no stress and nothing to hold it, it is free to straighten out.  This creates what is effectively a "straightening wave" as the whole free end now wants to become completely straight (all the way to your hand). 
...
This wave very quickly travels away from the first break in both directions.  When it gets to some point that is very close to the breaking point (breaking stress), it causes the bend to exceed the breaking point somewhere. 
...
You can see the result of this "transverse" type of wave within the short center piece as a complex wiggle immediately after the second break.   It is a half wave, open ended wiggle.  This is a sine wave, but from one positive peak to the next negative peak (not between zero crossings because the ends are free).
...
This analysis assumes that the spaghetti is not bent into a completely uniform circle, but some kind of an arch, or parabola-like curve that has more bend and stress at the top. .  This is because the breaks must both be near the area of maximum stress and the bend and stress must decrease as you move off center. 
...
 Because of this last observation, I also can speculate that *if* you can bend it into a very uniform circle shape where it is all bent at the same radius, that you will more often get multiple center pieces and if you make sure it is a non circle parabola-like shape, that you rarely get more than one center piece.
...
Keep in mind that the spaghetti will not have uniform breaking point all along the length, so the breaks will have a random factor as well. 
...
I also think that by carefully putting small notches in carefully choosen places, that you can get some spectacular results...  Have fun...
--

Hi Destin,

I want to start off by saying I'm a huge fan of your videos.  I can't imagine how you find the time to be an engineer, raise kids, and still have time to do these videos to push scientific knowledge on everyday phenomenon.  Thank you for making these awesome videos.

Anyways, I watched your spaghetti snapping video a few times and had trouble understanding your conclusion of the secondary break being caused by the small section straightening out.  After watching the 250k FPS video (4:23 to 4:25) a dozen more times, I saw something more.  I saw a transverse sinusoidal wave rippling across the spaghetti that causes the secondary break.

The small section that breaks off starts straightening out at the primary breakage point.  This point is the first crest of the sine wave.  In the 250k FPS video, you can see a trough forming in this small section followed by another crest.  This secondary crest causes bending beyond the minimum bend radius and thus causes the secondary breakage.  What's interesting is that the small sections that break off are all one wavelength long or integer multiples of one wavelength.  Your video at 5:18 shows three small sections that break off.  The first and second sections are both one wavelength long.  The third section is two wavelengths long.

Since the "natural" wavelength is dependent on the mechanical properties of the spaghetti, small fluctuations in the thickness of the spaghetti will cause a slightly different natural wavelengths.  I think this causes slightly different lengths to break off, but in general, the sections that break off are integer multiples of the spaghetti's "natural" wavelength.

What do you think Destin?  I'd love to hear your thoughts on this.  I e-mailed you about this and attached a diagram.

Have you ever given a garden hose a quick shake and then watched the resulting bend travel out away from you for a surprising distance? Fly fishermen know this phenomenon as mending, when they throw a loop out from the end of their pole to manipulate the position of line on the water. The loaded energy travels down the fly line, or hose, or spaghetti just behind the loop, or kink. In the case of the very fragile spaghetti, a fracture occurs at the top of the loop, at the point of maximum flex. But the energy travelling down the rod is behind the loop, remember. So when the break occurs, the end whips downward like a bow, making the short piece spin in the opposite direction of the loop curve. The energy travels in a straight line, so it forces the free end to move towards it, down from the loop. But it does seem that there are at least two types of energy in the spaghetti. There is the energy stored and released in the original flex, and there is also the shock wave travelling down the rod which has been released by the previous break. Before any break occurs, the energy is stored somewhat evenly along the length of the rod. A break focuses some of that energy, which then becomes a shock wave, but there is still energy left in the remaining bend. That is why the spaghetti goes through all those contortions.

At time 4:24 the initial break occurs at -2283.289 ms and 0.048 ms later the second occurs at -2283.241 ms.  If I assume the spaghetti has a nominal diameter of 2 mm then the distance between the first and second fracture is ~24 mm, yielding 500 meter/second (1648 ft/sec, 1118 mph).  I would guess this figure is ±20% as the spaghetti diameter is a total Wag and the camera clock counts in 0.004 ms intervals (plus everything else).

Hate to burst your bubble, but this isn't groundbreaking stuff. I mean.. maybe in the 'slow-motion video of spaghetti’ world, sure. What you failed to mention is why the mechanism of spaghetti differs from that of, say… steel for example. Assume you apply bending moments, due to downward forces like you did in the video, on both ends of the steel [beam] in equal and opposite magnitudes and directions, respectively. Undoubtedly, a steel beam--like spaghetti and every other material--will experience stresses (in this case, bending stresses), whereby the fracture plane should occur at the middle of its length and extreme fiber of its cross-section. But why doesn’t the spaghetti behave in the same way? 

The simple answer is that spaghetti is not completely solid; it is a tube. When a tube is bent, the outer wall becomes thinner due to tension, while the inner wall becomes thicker due to compression; this explains why the outer wall of each piece breaks first. It breaks in a downward compressive manner, followed by the upward tensile direction of the other end. Additionally, as a result of bending, the tube exerts an internal pressure. The internal pressure causes what is known as ‘hoop stress’, which behaves differently for thin-walled vs. thick-walled tubes. 

To determine which case it is, we must first make some observational deductions from the geometry of the spaghetti. Since it ‘appears’ solid, it must mean that the radius-to-thickness ratio is less than 10, meaning it must be a thick-walled tube. Thick-walled tubes behave in such a way that the stresses vary significantly between the inner- and outer-walls, also explaining why the thinner (due to bending) outer-wall breaks first. Essentially, the bending stress in the spaghetti acts concurrently with hoop stress, thus accounting for ‘premature’ fracturing and thus the additional fracture planes.

Breaking spaghettis before cooking them is a sin... All you have to do is lay them all around the pot, and push them in as they soften going from one side to the other. The end result will look like a bird's nest, or a Rodin coil. Interestingly, because each spaghetti is pushed by its neighbor in one direction which then influences the neighbor, the spaghetti will align in a "vortex shape", cook evenly, and be very pretty as they cook.
Also, putting olive oil in the water will help them not stick to each other. Get smarter everyday I guess ?

Theory: you have a relatively constant bending moment throughout the entire length of the piece of pasta due to equal torque applied at the ends, but the pasta is not uniformly thick (though for eating purposes, it appears to be uniformly thick).  The thinner portions have lesser section moduli and moments of inertia.  It will break at these locations first, and relieve the stress in the remaining portions of the piece.  Am I wrong?  Yeah, probably.  But heck, speculating didn't cost me anything, eh?

This is exactly what I expected, it has to do with the curve. Breaking a pencil is dissimilar because it retains it's typical structure of non-curvature. Spaghetti can have two points of force at the base where the curve forms an arc. Thus, if you were to snap a spaghetti without bending it, it will surely break into only two pieces.
